output.conclusion: By completing this course, you will have a strong understanding of microservices architecture, its benefits, challenges, and best practices. You'll be equipped to design, build, and deploy microservices-based applications effectively.
output.introduction: Welcome to the Advanced Microservices Architecture course! This course is designed for experienced developers and architects who want to delve deeper into the complexities and best practices of building and deploying microservices-based applications. We will cover advanced topics such as service mesh, observability, security, and advanced deployment strategies.

chapters.description: A brief overview of microservices architecture, its benefits, and drawbacks. Comparison with monolithic architecture. Key principles of microservices design.
Exploring different strategies for decomposing a monolithic application into microservices. Domain-Driven Design (DDD) as a guiding principle.
Synchronous vs. Asynchronous communication. REST, gRPC, and message queues. Choosing the right communication pattern for different scenarios.
Introduction to service meshes like Istio and Linkerd. Understanding the benefits of a service mesh for microservices.
Using service mesh features for traffic management, including routing, load balancing, and canary deployments.
Implementing security policies and observability features within the service mesh. Mutual TLS, tracing, and monitoring.
Implementing distributed tracing with tools like Jaeger or Zipkin. Understanding trace context propagation.
Collecting and analyzing metrics for microservices. Using Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring.
Centralized logging and log aggregation. Best practices for logging in a microservices environment.
Implementing authentication and authorization in microservices. Using OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect.
Securing communication between microservices with TLS and encryption. Protecting sensitive data.
Securing APIs with API gateways and security policies. Protecting against common API vulnerabilities.
Implementing blue-green deployments for zero-downtime releases. Rolling back deployments in case of issues.
Using canary deployments to test new features with a small subset of users. Monitoring performance and stability.
Using feature flags to enable or disable features without redeploying code. A/B testing with feature flags.
